title: Traditional Gyro Meat Recipe
description: This Greek/Lebanese-style gyro meat is delicious sliced and served with fresh pita bread, tzatziki, and tomatoes for a Mediterranean meal.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Main Dishes Meatloaf Recipes Traditional Gyro Meat 4.6 (346) 280 Reviews 53 Photos This delicious gyro meat is the closest I've come to emulating my favorite Mediterranean restaurant's recipe. The Greek/Lebanese-style meatloaf is sliced and served with pita bread, tzatziki, and tomatoes. The preparation time seems long, but most of it is resting time, so you can be doing other things!  Submitted by The Dread Pirate Paramour Updated on April 11, 2024 Tested by Craig Ruff Tested by Craig Ruff Craig Ruff is a dedicated cook and lover of food science. His culinary background comes from culinary school and his time working in restaurants. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 53 53 53 53 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 1 hr Additional Time: 1 hr Total Time: 2 hrs 15 mins Servings: 10 Yield: 1 (7x4-inch) loaf Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe “The gyro meat is moist, tender, and super aromatic from the dried herbs,” says Allrecipes recipe tester Craig Ruff. “It would be perfect in a gyro with all the fixings. It’s super versatile and rather easy.” How to Make Gyro Meat You'll find a detailed ingredient list and step-by-step instructions in the recipe below, but let's go over the basics: What Is In Gyro Meat?  This gyro meat recipe calls for a pound of ground lamb and a pound of 80 percent lean (20 percent fat) ground beef. It also features an onion and lots of seasonings.  Gyro Meat Seasoning This gyro meat is seasoned with minced garlic, dried oregano, ground cumin, dried marjoram, ground dried rosemary, ground dried thyme, ground black pepper, and fine sea salt.  How to Make Gyro Meat at Home Here’s a brief overview of what you can expect when you make homemade gyro meat:  Pulse the onion in a food processor, then squeeze in a towel to drain.  Combine the onions with the remaining ingredients in a bowl. Mix with your hands until well-combined, then chill.  Place meat mixture into a food processor and pulse until finely chopped and tacky. Place the loaf pan in a roasting pan lined with a damp kitchen towel.  Pour boiling water into the pan until it comes halfway up the sides of the loaf pan. Bake until the loaf is no longer pink in the center.  Pour off any accumulated fat, let cool slightly, then slice thinly. Serving Tip Serve the gyro meat wrapped in warm pita bread and topped with tomatoes, onions, feta, and tzatziki.  Test Kitchen Tips This top-rated user recipe was tested in our test kitchen. Here are some tips from our recipe testers: The meat is easier to slice if it is chilled. Use a sharp chef’s knife for thin slices. Processing the meat in the food processor and overworking it ensures that the proteins in the meat stick together, like sausage. Essentially, this prevents the meat from falling apart.  Use all lamb, all beef, or substitute the lamb for sausage. Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 10 servings ½ medium onion, cut into chunks 1 pound ground lamb 1 pound 80/20 ground beef 1 tablespoon minced garlic 1 teaspoon dried oregano 1 teaspoon ground cumin 1 teaspoon dried marjoram 1 teaspoon ground dried rosemary 1 teaspoon ground dried thyme 1 teaspoon ground black pepper 1½ teaspoons fine sea salt cooking spray Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Pulse onion in a food processor until finely chopped, about 5 (1-second) pulses. Scoop onions onto the center of a towel, gather up the towel ends, and squeeze to remove liquid. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Combine onions, lamb, beef, garlic, oregano, cumin, marjoram, rosemary, thyme, pepper, and salt in a large bowl. Mix with your hands until well combined. Cover and refrigerate 1 to 2 hours to allow the flavors to blend. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Evenly coat a 9x5-inch loaf pan with cooking spray. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Working in 2 batches if necessary, place meat mixture into a food processor and pulse until finely chopped and the texture feels tacky, about 1 minute. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Transfer mixture into prepared loaf pan, and pack down to make sure there are no air pockets. Line a medium roasting pan with a damp kitchen towel. Place the loaf pan in the center of the towel-lined roasting pan, and transfer it into the preheated oven. Carefully pour boiling water into the roasting pan until it comes halfway up the sides of the loaf pan. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bake in the preheated oven until gyro meat is no longer pink in the center, about 1 hour to 1 hour 25 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 160 degrees F (70 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Pour off any accumulated fat, and allow to cool slightly before slicing thinly and serving. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Serve and enjoy! Dotdash Meredith Food Studios From the Editor This recipe was tested in our test kitchen in November 2023 and updated to increase the cooking time and amount of salt based on user feedback. The original recipe used ¼ teaspoon of salt. I Made It Print 624 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 258 Calories 17g Fat 1g Carbs 24g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 10 Calories 258 % Daily Value * Total Fat 17g 22% Saturated Fat 7g 33% Cholesterol 84mg 28% Sodium 396mg 17% Total Carbohydrate 1g 0% Dietary Fiber 0g 1% Total Sugars 0g Protein 24g 47% Vitamin C 1mg 1% Calcium 35mg 3% Iron 3mg 14% Potassium 348mg 7% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Traditional Gyro Meat 01 of 53 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 53 Photo by  Maria Cartagena 03/24/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Worth the effort I must say I thought I could never make gyro meat from home until I ran into this recipe. At first I was hesitant because I never used the ingredient marjoram. I was unfamiliar with it until I Google as it belongs to the mint family. The recipe is very easy. I bought all the ingredients it required and followed the recipe to the "T". I had fun making this recipe. I also questioned the purpose of the towel and what I come up with is for moisture (maybe?). Now I understand when it said to leave recipe for two hours in the fridge. That is when all the ingredients blends in for more flavor. The meat and ingredients are very aromatic. Would I do this receipe again? YES. Overall highly recommend. 03 of 53 Photo by  DaMárie 07/07/2022 This was my first time making gyros and it was fun. Turned out great and was a hit! 04 of 53 Photo by  CalmPan6072 03/21/2022 This recipe is just about perfect, and very satisfying. I do not have a food processor, so I mixed the meat + ingredients with a potato masher and it worked well. The meatloaf needed over an hour at 325 F degrees in my convection oven, and recipe can easily double the salt (increase to 1/2 tsp of salt) without peril. Recommend resting the loaf for 15 minutes before slicing. Then, suggest hitting the slices on a med-hot griddle/frying pan for 30 sec to a minute per side - it browns up just like at restaurants and food trucks. Have seen and eaten identical texture at gyro places in NY, so I'm happy with a slightly grainier texture. Definitely better and richer tasting the second day. Best served with pita, tomatoes, onion, and tzatziki - I eliminated the pita as I'm gluten allergic - also, great for breakfast! 05 of 53 Photo by  Recipes Worth Keeping 06/20/2021 Just waiting have 45 minutes and the cooling time before slicing up a sandwich yum was easy to assemble 06 of 53 Photo by  Recipes Worth Keeping 06/20/2021 Just waiting have 45 minutes and the cooling time before slicing up a sandwich yum was easy to assemble 07 of 53 Photo by  The Real Becky 05/08/2021 The recipe was easy to make but personally I think it lacked seasoning. Maybe adding extra would help. Also the texture isnt quite right. Overall it was pretty good. 08 of 53 Photo by  Jeremiah Valdez 02/03/2021 Recipe was killer! Added a little more salt and garlic though, and after slicing I seared it in a frying pan to give it a little bark. 09 of 53 Photo by  sweet lady 10/19/2020 10 of 53 Photo by  tcurti 09/29/2020 I’ve made this a few times and it’s simply delicious. The whole family loves it and it makes wonderful leftovers. One thing I do differently is cut thin slices and then before serving, give the slices a quick sear I’m a cast iron skillet. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Gyros Burgers 295 Ratings American Gyros 92 Ratings Greek Souzoukaklia 105 Ratings Meat and Spinach Ravioli Filling 42 Ratings Beef Pastitsio 19 Ratings Beef Gyro 29 Ratings Barbacoa 29 Ratings Loaded Greek Burgers 28 Ratings Meatloaf Roll 13 Ratings Traditional Gyros 37 Ratings Margaret's Keftedes (Greek Meatballs) 83 Ratings Greek Meat Pasta (Makaronia me kima) 5 Ratings Slow Cooker Ground Beef Barbecue 123 Ratings Air Fryer Mini Italian Meatloaves for Two Turkish Doner Kebab 6 Ratings Pastitsio IV 26 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. Scoop onions onto the center of a towel, gather up the towel ends, and squeeze to remove liquid. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Combine onions, lamb, beef, garlic, oregano, cumin, marjoram, rosemary, thyme, pepper, and salt in a large bowl. Mix with your hands until well combined. Cover and refrigerate 1 to 2 hours to allow the flavors to blend. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Evenly coat a 9x5-inch loaf pan with cooking spray. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Working in 2 batches if necessary, place meat mixture into a food processor and pulse until finely chopped and the texture feels tacky, about 1 minute. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Transfer mixture into prepared loaf pan, and pack down to make sure there are no air pockets. Line a medium roasting pan with a damp kitchen towel. Place the loaf pan in the center of the towel-lined roasting pan, and transfer it into the preheated oven. Carefully pour boiling water into the roasting pan until it comes halfway up the sides of the loaf pan. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Bake in the preheated oven until gyro meat is no longer pink in the center, about 1 hour to 1 hour 25 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 160 degrees F (70 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Pour off any accumulated fat, and allow to cool slightly before slicing thinly and serving. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Serve and enjoy! Dotdash Meredith Food Studios
